Dear [EMAIL]

[CUSTOM_URL]

- Online surveys Team

children.label: b74825825
children.text:
Thank you for agreeing to participate in Round 4 of the ENLIGHT survey. We look forward to receiving your input. Please note that to qualify for contributorship under a group authorship model, you must complete Rounds 1, 2, and 4.

Following Round 3, we have made numerous changes in the checklist by identifying common thematic clusters brought up in the synchronous Round 3 discussions (see attachment to the invitation email). These changes have simplified, condensed, and improved the checklist.

We have also written guidelines explaining concepts contained in the checklist. These guidelines are kept concise, and are only intended to help authors complete the checklist and are not intended to provide a comprehensive guide on how to design studies or perform light measurements.

In Round 4, we will ask for your input on which items in the checklist should be reported in studies irrespective of the specific context or study design. Items which more than 75% of experts believe should be reported irrespective of context will have the “not applicable” box removed in the final checklist to indicate that the item is applicable regardless of context. All items will still have a "not available" box for authors to tick.

We will also ask you to review both the Checklist and Guidelines and provide any final feedback. Please ensure any feedback is concise, specific, and actionable. Similarly to Round 3, we will group common themes that arise from the written feedback and make changes to the guidelines and/or checklist as appropriate.

Please remember: The checklist and guidelines are intended for use in human in-laboratory studies of the non-visual effects of light. We appreciate that there are other contexts, for example field research, where some of the items in the checklist may not be available or measurable. However, the development of a checklist which additionally covers these contexts is beyond the scope of the current exercise.

children.label: b74924678
children.text: Please enter your unique 5-character ID.

children.label: b74883023
children.text:
Here, we ask you to indicate which reporting items should always be reported, irrespective of context, design or other specific aspects of the study. When we receive a consensus agreement of 75% that the item should always be reported, the "Not applicable" checkbox will be removed from the final version of the checklist.

We note that indicating something should always be reported, does not prescribe a specific way of designing or running a research study.

Example 1: Indicating “yes” for “Pre-laboratory sleep-wake/rest-activity behaviour” (Section A1) would mean that you think that the not-applicable box should be removed for this item in the checklist. Therefore, authors would always need to either describe how “Pre-laboratory sleep-wake/rest-activity” was measured/controlled, OR state explicitly in the manuscript that it was not measured/controlled, OR indicate that it is not available in the checklist.

Example 2: Indicating “no” for “Wearable light-filtering apparatus” (Section B1) would mean that you think that the not-applicable box should always be available for authors completing the checklist.

children.label: b74965874
children.text: A.1. Protocol-level characteristics

children.label: b74883039
children.text: Should the following protocol-level characteristics always be reported, irrespective of context, design or specific aspects of a study?

children.label: b74883058
children.text: Description of experimental setting

children.label: b74883060
children.text: Timeline of experiment (including timing and duration of light)

children.label: b74883062
children.text: Pre-laboratory sleep-wake/rest-activity behaviour

children.label: b74924301
children.text: Pre-laboratory light exposure

children.label: b74924303
children.text: Immediate prior light exposure (in laboratory)

children.label: b74965921
children.text: A.2. Measurement-level characteristics

children.label: b74924344
children.text: Should the following measurement-level characteristics always be reported, irrespective of context, design or specific aspects of a study?

children.label: b74924346
children.text: Measurement plane (e.g., horizontal or vertical)

children.label: b74924348
children.text: Measurement viewpoint and location

children.label: b74924350
children.text: Type, make and manufacturer of the measurement instrument

children.label: b74924352
children.text: Calibration status of the instrument

children.label: b74965933
children.text: A.3. Participant-level characteristics

children.label: b74924358
children.text: Should the following participant-level characteristics always be reported, irrespective of context, design or context, design or specific aspects of a study?

children.label: b74924359
children.text: Pupil size and/or dilation

children.label: b74924361
children.text: Relative time (e.g. to circadian phase or sleep)

children.label: b74924363
children.text: Ocular health and functioning

children.label: b74965939
children.text: B.1. Light source characteristics

children.label: b74924426
children.text: Should the following light source characteristics always be reported, irrespective of context, design or specific aspects of a study?

children.label: b74924427
children.text: Type, make and manufacturer of the light source

children.label: b74924429
children.text: Use of wearable filtering apparatus (e.g., blue-blocking glasses)

children.label: b74965324
children.text:
B.2. Light-level characteristics

For these items, indicating “yes” would mean that you think either the illuminance/irradiance or luminance/radiance for each item should always be reported, depending on the type of light source, not that both should be.

children.label: b74924533
children.text: Should the following light-level characteristics always be reported, irrespective of context, design or specific aspects of a study?

children.label: b74924534
children.text: Spectral irradiance OR radiance distribution

children.label: b74924536
children.text: Illuminance (lux) OR luminance (cd/m2)

children.label: b74924539
children.text: α−opic irradiance OR radiance (including melanopic)

children.label: b74924541
children.text: α−opic equivalent daylight illuminance OR luminance (EDI/EDL, including melanopic)

children.label: b74965421
children.text:
B.3. Colour chacteristics

For “Peak wavelength/bandwidth”, these items are only relevant to narrow-band/monochromatic light sources, as already noted in the checklist. Therefore, if you select “yes” below, this would indicate that where narrow-band/monochromatic light sources are selected in Section B.1, you think that the not-applicable option should be removed for “Peak wavelength/bandwidth”.

children.label: b74965844
children.text: Should the following colour characteristics always be reported, irrespective of context, design or specific aspects of a study?

children.label: b74965846
children.text: Peak wavelength and bandwidth

children.label: b74965849
children.text: Colour quantities (any)

children.label: b74965851
children.text: Colour rendition metrics (any)

children.label: b74966028
children.text: B.4. Temporal and spatial characteristics

children.label: b74924555
children.text: Should the following temporal and spatial characteristics always be reported, irrespective of context, design or specific aspects of a study?

children.label: b74924556
children.text: Temporal pattern (including flash frequency and waveform)

children.label: b74924558
children.text: Location of stimulus and viewing distance

children.label: b74924560
children.text: Relative or absolute size of the stimulus

children.label: b74826570
children.text: Do you have any open comments on the checklist? Please be concise and specific.

children.label: b74826939
children.text: Do you have any open comments on the guidelines? Please be concise and specific.

children.label: b74825956
children.text:
As indicated in our invitation email, participants completing Rounds 1, 2 and 4 can be included on the manuscript describing the checklist, guidelines and the process by which the checklist were derived as contributors in a group authorship model. Completing Round 4 will make you eligible for inclusion in the consortium.

In the following section, we explicitly ask you to give your permission to be included as a contributor and ask for the name and email address with which you would like to be included. Please note that there will be no explicit opportunity to comment/provide feedback on the manuscript. However, prior to submission (either to a journal or pre-print server) you will receive a confidential copy of the manuscript, and be able to withdraw your contributorship if you no longer wish to be involved.

children.label: b74827609
children.text: Do you wish to be named as part of the ENLIGHT consortium and be a contributor following the group authorship model?

children.label: b74827064
children.text: Your first name (including any initials) as you wish it to appear on MEDLINE

children.label: b74950838
children.text: Your last name as you wish it to appear on MEDLINE

children.label: b74827067
children.text: Your email address

children.label: b74827164
children.text: Your ORCID

children.label: b74827617
children.title: Reason for not joining the group authorship

children.label: b74827622
children.text: What are your reasons for not joining the ENLIGHT consortium as a contributor on the publication?

children.label: b74882931
children.title: Evaluation of the modified Delphi process

children.label: b74882949
children.text:
We would like to ask you to evaluate the modified Delphi process which we have implemented as part of the ENLIGHT project. We ask you to evaluated the process separately from the outcome.

We would like to thank you again for your time and contribution. We really appreciate your ongoing involvement.

children.label: b74882940
children.text: How satisfied are you with the ENLIGHT modified Delphi process?

children.label: b74882950
children.text: How satisfied are you with the ENLIGHT checklist?

children.label: b74882952
children.text: How satisfied are you with the ENLIGHT guidelines?

children.label: b74883149
children.text: Thank you participating in the ENLIGHT project. We appreciate the time and effort you have put into this.
